Description: Body sherd of Chian pottery patterned chalice; white slip; interior glazed streaky black; exterior: group of vertical strokes in handle zone; at bottom of sherd, traces of black band.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Ure Museum of Greek Archaeology, Reading. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

For parallels, see Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology NA274 and British Museum 1886,0401.1042. Lemos (1991, 12) explains that this chalice 'belongs to a group of chalices with broad bowls decorated on the handle zone with two saw-edged patterns flanked by three sets of stripes, which appear on the other side of the vessel'. The Ure Museum received sherds from the Egypt Exploration Society (EES) in 1926, several years after Petrie and Gardner's excavations. It was uncertain then whether the sherds came from Naukratis or Tell Dafana, a site in the eastern Nile Delta that was excavated by Petrie in 1886. Petrie wrote that he found only one sherd of Chian ware at Tell Dafana (Petrie 1888 62), which he described as a plain piece, thus the Chian sherds in the Reading collection come from Naukratis.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 233, pl. 6, no. 67)
CVA Reading I / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain, Fasc. 12, University of Reading (p. 37, pl. 23, no. 5a-b)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0353) (phase 2)
